reviews.review: When Awesome Nature meets Great Arts. I'm rarely visited Museum when I'm on holiday, but my friend make me visits Don Antonio Blanco Museum. First, I amazed by the natural surroundings, you'll more amazed when you look at the second floor of the museum. The paintings that Don Antonio was make are so unique and awesome! The techniques how and why and the stories behind every paintings, also the puzzles of those paintings will blow your mind! Me and my friends was take on your by museum guide there. She's told us every each details. Totally would take my friends and family to visit here.

Good but pricey. Overall you pay too much for what you get to see. The grounds around the museum are beautiful. The artwork was also good but much of it was the same. The was no range or depth to the art.

Spain meets Bali. This is a modern art museum, with a bit of Gaudi style (Blanco is originally from Catalonia, although born in Philippines and similarly unconventional). Very different to everything else on Bali and therefore definitely worth a visit.

Great Art work by European artist settled in Bali. Great piece of Art displayed here along with access to the Artists Studio & home. Now the legacy is carried forward by his equally talented son. It takes about 1 hour to go around the awesome museum to enjoy & appreciate the artwork. Balinese women portrayed in an artists vision is the theme of this museum & strongly recommended along with ARMA ( Ayung Rai Museum of Arts ) for Art lovers.
A surprising museum. This museum is most unexpected in Bali. It is very ornate but we thought the paintings really beautiful. It is a small walk out of town but well worth the walk.

So-so place in Ubud!. Of our 5 day trip to Bali, the third day was planned for Ubud. We started with Antonia Blanco Museum considering their timings. The little green lawn had most varied Birds.The Big Black crows and Parrots were of the size of Swan :)The museum has vintage paintings. Nothing so exciting.

flamboyant display. I had read up on the museum prior to going to Bali. It was a place i was interested to see. Now that i have been through the museum not sure that a collection of topless balinese women painted in varies styles with frames to match would drag me back for a second look. If you are in Ubud stop in the museum is not huge so you can wander through quickly if short of time.

Kinda lame paintings, very colonial. No way is this guy the Bali Dali, his paintings are definitely colonial era, the nubiile Bali breast through the perving gaze of the Italian painter. I wasn't impressed by his paintings, and there was little to no social commentary or anything about his wife the dancer. I much prefer Balinese wood carvings to this- very European and somewhat out of place.
must visit of UBUD. Its a Museum currently maintained by son of Antonio, but DON ANTONIO has made his fantastic work of art with his own family members, mainly nude art work

Interesting place. I didn't know what to expect from a visit of the museum. I was well surprised. The birds inside are beautiful and you can catch them and take photos. Don Blanco has become an inspiration for me after seeing his artwork. Really nice place.
Never thought Bali in 1900 could be this exciting. I never know that Balinese woman having that kind of life. Antonio capture it very nicely and they also have a very nice restaurant.

First fascination, then distaste. Once you climb the very steep hill to this ego-shrine of the artist, you are in a beautiful, well-kept, secluded green space above the city. The views from the restaurant where you get your artsy miniscule free post-visit drink are splendid and there is a breeze thanks to the elevation - might be worth climbing up just for that. The place is quite magical as you walk and discover different parts of the complex. The approach is often irreverent or light-hearted, e.g. the pompom earrings and marigold garland on the Ganesha statue form a smiley face as you ascend the stairs. The setting is glorious. Then you unexpectedly come to an area where a number of spectacular large colourful tropical birds are perched on a branch. A handler can put them on your person for photos if you wish. There is no denying these birds are majestic and breathtaking. Just wow at first, and then you start wondering how come these huge creatures just sit there on the branch all day and how they have been treated and trained (and their wings possibly clipped?) to provide tourist entertainment. One was jumping up and down as if he wanted to take flight somehow, despite the odds. You can see the cages with their successors from the windows of the gallery. The leaflet briefly mentions conservation but this was not at all clear from the exhibit. You then enter the main museum building (no photos inside). The artist was somewhat talented as evidenced by a number of vaguely impressionistic portraits with a human spark in the eyes. He created elaborate stylized frames to go with his works - to me, while interesting, these are not appealing. They have a whimsical, vaguely shabby chic aesthetic. A terrace with gilded dancer statues surrounds the cupola - nice views again. The majority of the paintings are of native subjects (Balinese nubile women) in various states of undress. They always have their breasts exposed, frequently more. Some expat women are thrown in for good measure, sprawled naked across sofas and daybeds, more than once with a big round glass bottle for distilling wine straddled between their legs. I have nothing against nudity in painting. Yet, the works, which meld into one after a while, seemed to whisper to me of narcissistic ego-mania, exploitation, patriarchy and privilege - male, white and mystical-artsy. I felt uncomfortable for these women and the sleazy old uncle character (as another reviewer aptly put it) as artist approaching their innocent bodies for "art" or money. It is not something I endorse. Many people just seem to follow the it's-art-and-in-a-museum-so-it's-respectable-and-ok line but this seems facile. I have been to Dali's houses in Figueres and Cadaques and while extravagant and provocative, self-obsessed Dali at least was doing his own thing, the first to do so and constantly evolving, experimenting with all the power symbols and taboos, not just sex but also religion, power, masculinity, art norms, etc. In this light, his fellow Catalan seems like an imitator with a more traditional brush, more narrow interests (local perky breasts) and seaside-gallery frames that did not seem tongue-in-cheek in their kitsch. Superimposed with a copied Dali persona, including in the way he dressed. While side by side with Dali in his native Catalonia he would have been derided, his copycat mysterious Western artist-traveller persona had purchase where he ended up, and his white male artsy quirkiness earned him quite traditional privileges, including a huge prime piece of land from the local authorities, I fear, helping secure his position to attract new talent to pose for his works. It is a shame his artist son has decided to imitate his father's style exactly to the point you cannot tell them apart. I think a few frank interviews with the subjects would nicely balance out the exhibit. A beautiful, serene, quirky place with average art and worrying undertones for this viewer.

Blanco lives on in museum. After meeting Don in his studio pit in 1996, we were heartened to find that the museum ( it's really a massive gallery) had been established in memory of Ubuds famous artist. The museum is a "must see" for anyone interested in art. It was gratifying to see works exhibited by Antonio's son, who carries on the Blanco tradition. Staff were very welcoming and provided interesting explanation on the history of the gallery.

Magnificent Museum. Since we aren't allowed to take some photos, the fine arts by Sir Antonio Blanco already make us amazed. Ask for a guide to explain every detail of the painting. Bli Wayan is one of the guide who was lead us to every single painting which has a spectacular meaning. Only 30k for local tourist and 80k for foreigner.

Great artworks. If you enjoy good quality artwork this place is a must. An amazing building with an amazing story and collection of unique artworks by a master...beautiful garden and friendly knowledgable staff.

Spectacular environment with unusual paintings. First visit here after many Ubud stays. The main building is a mix of Spanish, Balinese and art-deco. Magnificent. Sweeping staircases, a vast number of fascinating paintings, statues, extensive bird life and great roof top views. The restaurant was also of a high standard and the staff especially friendly. Highly recommended. Worth at least an hour or so.

An interesting place. The legacy of his father is carried on by Mario Blanco. The exhibits and building are well done. We had met M Blanco some years before in the US and were glad to finally get to see the museum. Enjoyed the birds who will perch on you near the entrance too.

Strangely repellant ... mixed reaction. Hmm. I've decided I don't much like Blanco's art. Not a 'PC' thing to say about this museum, I know, but there we are. 'Western Decadence Enters Bali' sort of thing. However, it is worth visiting if you know his art a little and know you'll like it, but it is not to my taste. An interesting piece of 'recent history', though.The area immediately around the Museum is great for shopping and places to eat. The road up to Penestanan goes steeply up alongside the museum. Well worth a walk up there for juice bars, cafes, clothes shopping, also.

Don't miss this one. This is a very eclectic art collection and well worth a visit. The building is beautiful, the grounds are lovely to walk in and the birds are amazing. The story of the original artist sheds light on earlier times in Bali

A must visit place in Ubud. We visited this place at the end of August. Pay for the entrance fee at IDR 60k/person, and they give us a small flower, cute.From the entrance door, you will find a small bird park and may take pictures with them for free.Even we cannot take any pictures inside the museum, we enjoyed our moment here. And when you're about to finish your trip in here, don't forget to go to the restaurant for a drink or meal or even just to get your "free welcome drink".Either you are an art lover or not, this place is worth a visit when you're in Ubud.

Bohemian artworks in a lovely setting. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the museum after lunching at the adjacent restaurant above the river. Interesting paintings with unique frames, housed in a lovely building with exotic birds in the garden. If taking young children, we aware of the erotic works in one room.

One for the senses. This museum is spectacular a must for art lovers and the music played in background so fitting. Entrance includes a welcome drink in restaurant. I would love to have purchased a catalogue or similar but none available which was a shame. The gift shop has a selection of silver jewellery designed by his daughter which was tempting. Well worth the visit I loved this artist sensitivity and glimpses of humour and his amazing use of framing his work ❤️❤️

Love the architecture and the art collection. Tickets to enter this museum are quite affordable IDR 30.000 if i'm not mistaken, the interior and architecture are designed in renaissance style, by the time you enter this museum I feels like I am inside a museum in Europe not like in Bali .. The collection of paintings are amazing, it is the precious collection from the legendary painters Antonio Blanco stored in this museum, its a pretty surprising experience to see how He creates those paintings with mostly woman as the subject and a touch of erotic presentation which is amazing !

Magic!. One of the most beautiful and harmonious places you can visit! The painting are wonderfully mysterious and exotic (even the frames of the painting are works of art themselves) surrounded by a building of extreme beauty with a ganden where you can find harmony, tranquility and tropical colourful birds! The artist's study definetelly worth visiting also! Glad we went !!

Worth seeing for its ostentatious buildings!. A well know figure among the Balinese, they are very proud of him. Although an artist, I had never heard of him and hence wanted to have a look. He appears to be a Dali look alike with half the talent, but the building he had erected on the land the king gave to him is rather spectacular. Only a short walk from Ubud Palace or a cheap bike ride.

Unusual but interesting. Don Antonio certainly had an eye for the female form. His art is a bit avante garde and a little risque so I'll leave you to decide if you take the kids or not. The attached cafe/restuarant at the end of the tour is a great place to sit and contemplate what you've just seen and also just a great place to just sit.

A Nice Study on Ubud Art History. the story started when don antonio arrived in ubud and began to build a huge mansion that later become the nowaday museum. the museum contains the collection of his painting which some of it arent suitable to be seen by children because the nudity. the entrance fee is about 30k IDR. you can reach this place by heading to campuan ridge walk. you cant take any photograph inside

Wonderful museum of a revolutionary man's works. The Blanco Museum is a piece of world-renown located in the artsy, sleepy town of Ubud. It's more than just an art museum, however. Take a look at Mario Blanco's gallery attached to the main museum and see art continuing to transform and captivate. Take a few pictures with and visit the Blancos' sanctuary of birds. Have lunch at the restaurant overlooking the Ubud forests and hills. It's not just an art museum—it's a living art experience.

Amazing Painter. I have been visit Antonio Blanco Museum during afternoon.Cheap price and beautifull view from the top of the roof! The paint are psichedelich and original.If you pass from Bali don t miss this amazing site
Worth a Visit. Interesting art works, worth a visit. Be sure to see the erotic works in their own room, tucked off to the side.
awful. a monument to a narcissistic, sexually preoccupied painter, who had an overblown self importance and would now like to share that with the world......
Worth a visit. This was my 2nd visit, amazing place, and although I appreciated his paintings, I felt a lot of the art was in the incredible frames. Gardens and architecture are an added bonus.

The museum of the "local Dali". ... An interesting character, this Antonio Blanco! The museum is located in a part of his house, or should I say mansion!, and shows his love for the Balinese women.
The museum is not too crowded and definitely worth a visit.
The restaurant of the museum provides excellent food and a beautiful place to enjoy a drink afterwards.

Egomanical display of perverted self importance. OK...so what is it with old European male painters coming to Bali in the first half of the last century and exploiting the Balinese (culturally, sexually) by marrying their (very) young women, and then painting them in various states of undress? (Le Mayeur, Blanco.....)Blanco's museum is a temple to his narcissism...evident with the entrance way. His work is beautiful at times, at others, pornographic. His self-aggrandisement, both in his work and within the shrine..opps, sorry-museum, left me with distaste. And I had to pay for it...Imagine having to kiss the dirty old pervy uncle....same thing
Good complement. The venue is amazing. Many of the paintings are superb. I would recommend going here after having visited some of the "must have seen" museums. Also good for a rainy day.
Very Nice but not worth 80,000 IDR each. Art museum rather small but very nice. Most expensive admission fee of the day. Most huge temple complexes are only 30,000

Sex humour. One must visit with the guide avaiable there, the way guide explains , all his painting are sex humour, I found Micheal jackson one best, was shown at end, now its been taken care by his son.

Amazing building, paintings and gardens. Definitely worth the visit. The gardens are exquisite with toucans and parrots for the kids to pose with. The building itself is this rococo fantasy dropped in the middle of Bali with spiral staircases and Versace sofas complimenting the eclectic works by the artist. He has an energetic rough style that leaves the viewer to complete the picture, often complimented with frames that are more spectacular than the paintings. Possibly the only criticism is they should not have the painting inventory numbers (B54, A55 etc..) prominently displayed on the frames as this detracts from the visual impact.

Dali-esque Ego Trip One-Man Gallery. This is an artist who patterned his public persona on the great egoist Salvador Dali. Unfortunately, the degree of talent was not really commensurate with Dali. It does make an interesting tour, after you have seen all the other galleries in Ubud.
Property lost power at the start of our visit.. Waited about fifteen minutes, then requested a refund and left without the benefit of seeing anything in the museum.

Good history of the painter.. Museum shows Blanco's and his son painting. Pretty big place. Good place to enjoy art, especially painting. Just IDR 30k for each person to enter this place (include welcome drink).

Tropical gardens, grand house and plenty of art. What a pleasant way to escape the Bali heat and be surrounded with beauty. Upon entering through the gate one enters a magnificent tropical gardens, lovely exotic birds, a monkey here and there and then the grand house which architecturally seems to have a mix of Balinese and European features.The serpent sculptures on stair entrance to house, the gold Balinese dancer sculptures, the grand fountain etc, and then inside so much gold leaf, silk, furniture and collections in cabinets. Strong vibrant Colors on walls, elaborate staircase,Paintings mostly framed in elaborately carved frames - sounds over the top but does justice to art, furniture and artefacts.Did not know of this artist before visiting museum - he was eccentric,In both appearance and probably his Spanish background comes to the fore here. A bit "Dali" in some ways.Internationally acclaimed he married a Balinese dancer, settled in Bali, had a family and worked frenetically on his. Art. Obviously had intense passion for the female form and a majority of work there proves thatHouse was family home & studioWhich is still in use as son followed in Antonio's footsteps.Also a great gift shop on grounds selling jewellery and other Balinese goods - probably of better quality than markets (maybe)Also restaurant there which we stopped for refreshments and took in the well manicured garden.Attracts lots of visitors and there is an entrance fee. Well worth the visit

Bizarre as the man himself. Certainly original and highly flamboyant, this painter Antonio Bianco. But then, shouldn't they be? His graphic style, slightly obsessed, does have a message of kinds. Worth a look. There also great birds (toucans, parrots) to see.

Nice museum & house. It is in ubud area.not a lot of tourist come here or they dont like blanco's nude art of women.bt as he was a famous artist i seems all his paintings good.though i am not a good painting critics.the museum place have a bird park(small) & a restaurant with hibiscous flower ice tea.in museum it is a two story building with about 70 paintings.blanco's art emphasize nude women bt it is in a artistic way.nice place to see.bt no photography allowed in inside.
Quirky. Some interesting art pieces and great grounds, well maintained, avoidable if you have limited time on your hands.
Great. Impressive collection, unique place. Offers things that even when more common in Europe, they can't be find in Indonesia. A bit pricy.
Stunning paintings. This was a wonderful experience. The original paintings from Bali's past were beautiful.The grounds are lovely, the café has beautiful views. Well worth a visit

Interesting stop off in Ubud. Although the style of art was not really to my liking, if you are into portraits, especially of bare-breasted women, this is the place for you. Apart from that, the position is nice and they have a great collection of tropical parrots/birds who are happy to pose with you for a photo!

Only for real art lovers.. I visited this place in May 2016. I have to admit that i don't know much about art and kinda don't like it. I payed 6$ entrance for this place which is inordinate expensive for a museum in this place. Once you enter you walk through a very nice garden where you can take some photos with parrots, and then enter the main building of the museum. It is an old aristocratic building with two floors, all of them covered only by paintings of mr. Blanco which is kind boring. I cannot say i was impressed but i am amateur with art. After spending 30 min. inside we went to the terrace where there is an outdoor bar with one of the most amazing views and we were offered our welcome juice shoots.

A fusion of Dali and Bali. An interesting artist who paints with life and flamboyance and considers the framing of his paintings as part of the art work with some curious results but, unless you are particularly keen on art, you may find the cost a bit high. Do, however, visit to see the grounds and the quite spectacular building and the see the birds. It is just above Bridges restaurant and not far from Ubud's Bintang supermarket.

Gotta Do It... Just not with the kiddos.. Browsing earlier reviews, I see that it’s all been said before, so I’ll be brief. Should you go? Yes, go. The grounds, the building, and the art itself is worth seeing – you’re in Ubud, for crimminey’s sake. Go see the darn thing. It cost me 6 USD – and I got to pose with birds. The art itself? Well, I actually loathed it. **Maybe** one painting of a woman with her legs spread is artistic. Maybe. Probably not. But there were THREE (yeah, I counted). It wasn’t artistic; it was pornographic. I mean, probably 80% of the paintings were of nude women; that’s not surprising (unoriginal, but no surprise). But the legs spread? VULGER. But whatever. The walk there was nice, the building was very cool, and I have one more thing to add to my Life Experiences List. Just be sure to leave the kids outside with the parrots.

Good for the art. Can you name a period of art without nudity? Look at the whole...the facial expressions, the stories, the painterly techniques, the draughtsmanship, the humour, the frames and you have to fascinate with the decor and the rooftop statues. Forget the restaurant and the unseemly bird park ... A large aviary would be more fitting and kind! Walk to and fro...the taxi will be slower!

Not even a little bit worth it . I honestly don't think it's worth the 80k Rp entrance fee. The paintings are beautiful, but eventually his fascination with the female body got a bit weird for my taste, plus it's not a very long exhibition.I would definitely say give it a skip.
great house and greats of the artists. from tropical grounds and birds to the artists studio and great place to check out for art lovers and creatives
This great value. Loved the art and tranquility of this place,the restaurant is awesome.serving in card tea,we would loved to see the he evening show

Not impressed at all. Lots of dull water colored paintings of naked women with ornate frames. The building is beautiful with a grand entrance and a lovely garden. However the artist comes off as impressed with his own work with a very sexist feel in his paintings. The colors are not appealing and the overall feel of his work is dull. He does have an unusual and distinct style but not to my liking.
Great funky museum. Don Antonio must have been a quirky character, evident by the works of "art". Nevertheless, a fun visit and good see but not top of my list

An amazing palace built by a Spanish artist and his Balinese dancer bride. Don Antonio Blanco was born in The Philippines to Spanish parents. When he arrived in Bali he fell in love with a beautiful Balinese dancer and they build a huge palace which is now a museum with his studio and artwork. It is an interesting, but slightly indulgent place. Much of the artwork looked in need of restoration..
Dali of Bali. Fascinating artist with some very surrealist works. The building is beautiful too. Steep driveway to get there.
good collection. we visited in this museum and the collection really beautiful and high of history. Mr. Antonio was famous and made us really surprised with this place. recommend to visit.

Interesting. I thought this museum was interesting. He was very fixated on naked woman, that is very clear. Italian meets Balinese architecture The grounds are very well maintained and clean. Liked have photos with the birds

Can't be missed!. This is my 3rd visit to Ubud but my first visit to Blanco and can I say .. I wish I had visited Blanco each and every time I cam to Ubud. Don Antonio is such an inspiration and talent! Thank you to Mario Blanco for realising his fathers dream in creating the museum in honour of his father .. We spent a few hours here and absolutely loved the experience!!!!
Exotic draws with epic meanings. Should grab the guide of the museum!!! Drawings, words & the frame hide lot of meaning and jokes.. :D

Beautiful art and place. You can admire the Spaniard Don Antonio Blanco's beautiful paintings in The Blanco Renissance Museum in Ubud. The museum building as Don Antonio Blanco build on a hill in the center of Ubud and the area surrounding the museum is also worth seeing. We were impressed.

To be in Ubud and not visit Blanco museum means not be in Bali at all. I can say this is the wander of Bali itself.. One of most unique painter of 20th century. Can not discribe by words. You have to see this. I was there more than 20 times and every time I get such grate feeling. Can look hours on these paintings. Very very recommend to visit this place.

Well... Would be more pleasant if cooler in there . Blanco was definitely a flamboyant person. The museum was striking in terms of its architecture with spiral staircases but what we didn't find so endearing were the actual works that has its main subject matter bare breasted women everywhere we looked. I personally found it rather distasteful as it was overtly just about that. I did however find the frames for the works beautiful and conversation pieces themselves. My main grouse is that it was incredibly hot in the museum. The 2 fans on the first level just sent the warm air circulating just in that corner. I had to leave shortly after as I found the heat unbearable. It was much cooler outside in the open and the kids enjoyed taking photos with the birds, parrots and especially the hornbill which was the highlight of our visit. The restaurant had pleasant views and was great to chill in. Unlikely to return.

Surreal art and a great gallery space. If you have an appreciation for surrealist art and freaky cool architecture along with beaut gardens and birds then visit this gallery on the outskirts of ubud... I love it!
Very interesting!. A cool look into the artist. Grab one of the ladies that work in the gallery to explain the artwork, as it will make a lot more sense! Have fun with the birds at the entrance too.

They call Blanco the Dali of Bali.. The garden and the building is beautiful.. Inside there are two floors with only Blanco paintings. If you are not interested in art and paintings it must be boring. But I love art and Blanco had many intersted ideas worked out in his paintings. Another thing with Bali paintings are the frames. The frames are already a piece of art itselves. Blanco was a little bit naughty; so are his paintings of Bali beauties.

nice place for Ubud Readers and Writer"s Festival Events. At URWF enjoyed an atmospheric evening in the garden of Antonio Blanco's musty mansion watching Dayak dancers and films. Got a seen better days Napoli feeling of past wealth though still privately owned. Better things to see in Ubud unless a special event is held there.

Some good pieces, others not so good. I much preferred the Neka Art museum to this. Antonio Blanco is no Dali, despite references to him as the Dali of Bali. The grounds are somewhat interesting, but for 80k it's not terribly good value. The ticket price includes a free drink in the cafe. The main museum was okay but the attached erotica collection is in poor taste and the studio's, family photo display and gift shop all a little weird.
Brilliant. Awesome. No other word will do. Just awesome. The quality of the artwork & the magnificence of the buildings are an inspiration.

Well Perched!. Its an pretty and quaint walk to this museum, you feel you are entering a grand home at first! Nice work by the artist and he has a unique style that stands out from all the traditional art one sees around the island. Even his sons work is very good!The museum entry ticket entitles you to a free drink at the restaurant, the glass is so tiny it barely quenches your thirst! Since the weather is hot and humid a slightly larger glass could do the trick!

Amazing art.. A friend had told me about this place & I am so glad I went. The grounds were amazing & an interesting contrast to Baliese architecture. The gallery was extremely interesting & the studio an unexpected treat. The disappointing part was there was almost no information about the artist and the museum. The small leaflet available when purchasing the ticket was not really very satisfactory. I am sure that with only a little effort some information could be provided & this would improve the standing of this place & make it so much easier for people to enjoy not only the artwork but also the history.
Well worth a visit. Worth the walk up the driveway. Fascinating. An easy walk from main shopping area. Nice photo opportunities.

Erotic Paintings. Saw his movie a while a go and we happened to pass Ubud during our 2nd honeymoon trip and decided to make a stop. There's not much to see but the special room that holds Blanco's erotic paintings collection is interesting and worth the visit.

I thought it would be better. My mum and I went here as a friend had highly recommended it to her. This was not my cup of tea. My mum liked it but I thought it was going to be better. The entry fee was ok. But it was just a lot of nudes and that's not my thing. I thought there would be more variety but it was all very similar. Beautiful grounds though and an amazing building. Nice restaurant up high. Would only recommend to true Don Antonio Blanco fans. Not a place for kids either.

Overpriced museum with just one painter's nudes. The only thing positive about the museum was that there were these birds outside which a person allowed my daughter to hold and photograph. Other than this I would have given this 1*.For this price (80K per person) I would have expected an art museum with a good collection of paintings from several artists. It only has the owner Don Blanco's own paintings.Also the colonial dimension of European painter painting almost exclusively nudes of local women seemed a little disturbing.This place is absolutely not for families with children under say 15.
Adult Art. This museum features more adult art subjects and pictures. There are many nudes and sexual featured art work/poems
Nice grounds. OK, I admit I'm not much of an art expert hence the rating. Some of the works were quite different & ah, explicit. The grounds are nice tho.

Great Museum . Me and husband love this place. It has beautiful views and amazing birds at the entrance to have photos with.
The gallery was unique and we had a great lunch in Rondji Restaurant.

Great Staffs Boost the Point. For me personally, this museum is interesting and calming. Seeing those paintings and works of arts, made me realize that Don Antonio Blanco is quite a charming and humorist person. But nothing more than that, until I met this amazing staff who guided me in the museum. He was funny (unfortunately I forgot his name) and very smart. He asked me some trivia questions about the paintings at the museum. And finally, he offered me to do some photoshoots at the exact spots with Raffi Ahmad & Gigi's prewed photos (Indonesia's famous artist). It blew me away with laughter but he was really kind.

This place is very interesting. My friend took me to this museum . and we spent the day here . we explore every corner of this museum , have fun and take photographed everywhere . This place is very interesting . full of traditional and modern art . if you are a museum lover , you must come to this museum.

Good Museum for art lovers. The museum is located in a nice settings. Have great paintings inside. Museum is located is highly manicured garden with beautiful views. Unfortunately they will not let you take pictures inside the museum. Entrance fee is 80,000 IDR which includes a drink at the cafe.

well if Michael Jackson was his friend!!!. Truly a place like no other on Bali or in the world. stunning building and the paintings and works of art deserve a second and possibly third glance. Put yourself in his space!

Worth a look. Don Antonio sure liked his nudes. Some of the paintings are a little confronting so probably not really appropriate for children. A nice activity on a rainy day but better when its not as the café at the end is open air and a lovely place to sit and take it all in. Watch the stairs to the top floor (roof) as they are a little rusty and not for the faint hearted.
Not a great visit for the price. I am bit disappointed to see and experience this museum. This is bit expensive, again I don't want to see a nude picture after nude picture with my family.
Authentic beauty. Whole setting is beautiful, the garden, the house, birds flying around and mainly the paintings. Works of Don Antonio is unusual and catchy.

Tricky. You better have yourself guided by the staff, they would tell you something you may not ever think of those paintings. Paintings are actually very tricky and funny. My guide is Bli Wayan, he explained each paintings (which in a funny way), and he's good at photography too!✌️

Monumentally bad. It is quite extraordinary that this so-called 'Renaissance museum' should appear so high up the list of things to do in Ubud. As previous reviewers have noted, this outrageously camp piece of baroquery is less a museum than a monument to the over-inflated ego of one of the worst artists to have made landfall in the Spice Islands.Others have expressed more eloquently than I the ghastliness of it all, but I have to mention again the entrance made in the form of the artist's mirrored signature and carved from a 15-metre high block of stone in honour of this self-styled 'Dali of Bali'.It wouldn't be so bad if the works themselves were of any artistic merit. But they are not. As another reviewer has noted, invest your time and money instead in the excellent Puri Lukisan - the museum of Balinese art close to the Palace; you will be amply rewarded and leave Ubud feeling artistically and culturally refreshed.

Historic Accounts of early Bali. Visited here first time in March 2016. Interesting painting styles in the main halls. Building is fascinating. Studio and other rooms equally amazing. Great selection of birds, especially the endangered Bali Mynah - they have a breeding program for them.

Closest Museum to our hotel. I wouldn't do this a second time, but I was curious and now I've been. Blanco designed all the frames for his artwork so the frames are actually part of the art. I am glad I went but since most of us have limited time in Bali...

Home of Bali Art. Returning once more to the home of beautiful baliese art.
This collection of art is most different from most any Indonesian art i have ever seen.
Worthy of a visit for the art lover and set in most beautiful part of Ubud.
Highly recommended.

Art Museum in Ubud. It's so peaceful and well managed of the museum. It's not like an ordinary one. Full of art paintings around with a story behind it. You need to ask the guide to tell you about the story. It's recommended to be visited while you are in Bali.
Very beautiful art!. We were pleasantly surprised with these amazing paintings and the way they were all framed. Such attention to details!

A very interested place to visit in Ubud.. Very beautiful and peaceful set up.
Very nice pieces of Art.
Need time to appreciate all the exhibits.
The restaurant has fantastic views to enjoy a drink afterwards.

Lots of interesting art. Be sure to ask questions of the woman guide inside - many pieces have little stories behind them.
I found the restaurant prices to be on the high side and the mango cheesecake was with little mango flavour and the portion small - kinda artsy but not really great value.

Out of the ordinary museum. From historical to shocking on a property with beautiful gardens. It is worth traveling up the steepest hills I have even been on. There are steps, but once you get to the museum it is easy to move about. There are interesting nude paintings and a good video to view.

Dali-esque Painter. Gallery for the decent expressionist painter, who passed away in 1999. But to be honest, the gallery need more informations about the paintings, and absolutely need air conditioner.
After all, the paintings are great. Blanco's erotic-expressionism gave us intimate view in women's body as a special artistic muse.

Somewhat expensive but worth seeing Museum.. Memorable visit in Ubud are the Blanco museum. Fantastically located and built by a Dutch artist Don Antonio Blanco. He came to Bali in the 50's, stayed and married here. He painted little risque paintings with a penchant for pompous frames. He seemed to have Salvador Dali as idol. The museum was originally built on land that Ubuds king donated to him and built to keep his gallery. His son, also an artist, use today his father's painting studio.

Excentric artist . This was a really nice place to visit in Ubud. Lovely garden on a hill, the house of art gallery was really something. Real nice, entrance fee more expensive than others. We pay 150' rupiah for two. Real nice exhibition inside the gallery, some real nice paintings off 'Dali of Bali'

Waste of Money!. Ok the entrance fee isn't huge at 80k but it still didn't make this worthwhile. Guess I should have done my homework on the work of Blanco before going.. just turned out to be naked woman after naked woman and sorry but not done very well either.. but that obviously a personal opinion. what bugged me more was the terribly officious manner of the staff .. not used to having folks in Bali be so snooty.. other real sore point is the caged birds.. no need for this at all and as for the parrots - didn't know they were indigenous to Bali ..!! they would have been better off in their natural habitat in south America. The grounds and building are very lovely and there is a spectacular view from the top of the building but for me filled half an hour of my holiday

Interesting but not that great. We visited this museum with interest as I am an artist studying in Ubud. This is an example of a foreigner coming to Ubud and using it to his full advantage. His art is interesting but not representative of Bali at all. He is a Dali try hard. His son has carried on the fathers business trying to copy his work but just doesn't cut it. For a laugh visit this place but as an example of local art go to Tony Raka instead.

Amazing Museum of the Maestro . Amazingly beautiful about the Maestro painting and the story behind it. The Museum itself is located beside his house. Personally intimate story about the Maestro. Assisted by super friendly Mr.Wayan to the whole museum and told the story about it.

Heritage of Maestro Antonio Blanco. Bali's heritage. Amazing paintings about beautiful women in Bali made by Maestro Antonio Blanco. We are assist by super friendly Mr.Wayan take us to the top and told the story behind the Blanco's painting.

Not that great. Honestly, we had high expectations when we went there. But it wasn't that great. Felt like a Salvador Dali wanna be, came to Ubud.True, some paintings were good but nost of it we didn't like. At least the view from the restaurant was nice.

Art museum. The museum covers two stories and if you can, get a guide as they have all the knowledge (and speak very good English). Entrance fee includes a free drink at the restaurant. They have some exotic birds just hanging around waiting for a photo with you. Climb up the spiral staircase to the roof for a beautiful view. There is a 'no children allowed' room with some interesting paintings. This man had a wicked sense of humour!

Museum with no so many details. For me, was a waste of Time & Money...Just paintings displayed on the Museum with not too much details or description. If you are an art lover, probably you are going to enjoy it, but if you are not and you prefer to know Bali with beautiful landscapes and spiritual experiences... this is not your place. I've been in arts Museums in Colombia, Peru, Australia & Chile... and the experiences were awesome... but this is was not the case.And at the end they have a super expensive Souvenir Shop and a Restaurant with high rates as well.

One of the best museums in the home residence I have ever been in.. Amazing paintings, wonderful environment, great cultural inherit age surrounded by beautiful Bali nature. Frames of paintings are the separate art. Ideas of A. Blanco and crafted by Baleneze craftsmen. Must see if you are into art and visit Ubud.
Great museum for art lovers. Good collection of Antonio Blanco's paintings and collections. The museum itself has a nice garden one can enjoy.
Beautiful Day. This was very interesting and beautiful. Very cool art and grounds. It was a rainy day so it was something fun to do indoors and not very expensive. Lots of history.

Restaurant. Above the musuem. After viewing the museum I went up to the restaurant and absolutely enjoyed myself there. the young people managing and working at the restaurant are friendly and very helpful and it was a beautiful view and in addition everything tasted good I certainly recommend it to everybody living in Ubud and to the visitors too

Definitely worth a visit. This is just the most bizarre but fascinating place. Art work is good and the incorporation of the frames in to the art unusual and interesting. The art is housed in an out of place and over the top building that must be seen to be believed

Amazing Artwork. I've gone to art school and I haven't heard of Antonio Blanco before. The museum and the grounds are amazing! The artwork is outstanding! There are a few funny stories to tell about the paintings, we had one of the girls explain/tell it to us. Really gives his art a different perspective. At the end you can visit his studio, and Im sure if you had any questions just ask the staff. And then you can also enjoy a refreshing drink from the restaurant overlooking amazing views.

Good for art lover. I visited there when I came to Ubud last June. It is an art museum. Just like in Monumen Perjuangan Rakyat Bali, the museum has a park, a main building and some small building which also have some paintings in it. You can take some picture in these building, but not at the main. You only can see the paintings and the view from the top of the main building. There are some histories, too in the museum. When I explored the park, I also found a peacock and some parrots at the park. For a local tourist, i just spent 30k to get inside.You can go to museum Antonio by walking from The Monkey Forest, but it was around 2 km. I love to take a walk because I can have sightseeing along the way. There’s also a good spot when you getting near the museum and you can also crossed a beautiful bridge just next to the museum gate.
Mesmerising. I adorable mix of artistic talent to show local culture in an exotic environment. It was a fabulous start to my Bali experience

Outstanding Artworks and Place. This place is outstanding! I love not only the paintings but also the setting, the interiors, and also the cafe. Antonio Blanco has a very unique character in paintings, though his son has a little bit different one and yes he made it. He created another unique paintings and he shows his own character in it. The place is easy to reach in Ubud. You can also enjoy lunch in the cafe after enjoyed the artworks.Splendid!

Amazing place,. I loved this place, beautiful views, gardens and amazing birds at the entrance to have (free) photos with.The gallery was unique and paintings and frames interesting to say the least. After reading some of the other reviews of this place I had to see it for myself. It's not everyone's cup of tea, you either love it or hate it. I loved it!

Great Atmosphere and Love the Rondji resto. I was here!! where Don Antonio Blanco used to work and where today his son Mario Blanco continues to find success through his own painting. "The Blanco Renaissance Museum; Maestro Don Antonio Blanco". After looking around inside the museum in 1st and 2nd floor n njoy some photo session wt the birds I took arest at The Rondji. Overall it was a great day. Will be back again for the 3rd time wt other friends!!

Unusual art experience. The classification "museum" is a bit misleading as it is a huge house, set in a very nice garden that is filled mostly with the work of one man, Antonio Blanco. He truly must have been an interesting eccentric personality with local friends in high places such as the King of Ubud. From the top of the house you have a nice view of Ubud and its surroundings. As for the art, it is interesting albeit not quite my taste. The entrance tickets are on the pricey side. But while in Ubud, it certainly is worth a visit after which one can relax in the restaurant that is part of the complex.

Excentric Delight. My parents, artists from Canada and I enjoyed ourselves discovering the Dali of Bali's home. What a character he must have been. I recommend this for all people, children too will enjoy the birds and interesting layout of the galleries. Didnt try the restaurant, but menu looked very good.

Grotesque!. Taken in isolation, this "Musuem" could at best be considered a joke. But in the context of Bali, and more especially Ubud where art and harmony are everywhere, this place is quite grotesque. An unparalleled monument to egocentric narcissism, entrance is thru an archway formed by... the mirror-image of the "artist's" signature. Made of Italian marble it is 15 metres high because he was born on the 15th. As for his paintings, Blanco was clearly a competent draughtsman but his subject matter his sense of colour and overblown frames are totally kitsch. He even tried his hand at poetry, some of which is shamelessly on display, but like the rest it is total gibberish. One shudders to think what the Balinese must have thought of this pretentious rubbish as representative of Western art. To be avoided at all costs!

Influential Painter. Well worth the visit, a painter brought lot of his influence to local people, trained local talents, an erotic painter who came to Bali after the 2nd world war, got lot of support from the nobility in Ubud.

Nice scenary~. Relatively boring in the museum. Nothing much to see except for the paintings, maybe cuz I'm not that of an arty-farty person. The entrance tickets is quite costly at 80,000rup per pax which includes a v small drink. However, the scenery that u get to see from the top is fabulous!!! Me n my hubby couldn't stop taking photos of the scenery from the top of the museum and the cafe. Overall, it's a nice place to hangout.

Great museum. Overall it's a great museum, the building itself and its paintings. Taking picture inside with the painting is not allowed but you can take pictures on top of the buildings, and with the birds outside the main building. I would say that the museum is more suitable for adults. You have to approach one of the guide to explain the story behind the paintings as there are several paintings with tricks and hidden meaning. Our guide Pak Wayan is really helpful and friendly.

Excellent garden, great architecture and statues, normal art work, pricy tickets. The garden is quite interesting and beautiful, and the statues at roof top is superb, also there is great view from their restaurant. But the art work is quite normal, and food price in the restaurant is high considering it's Bali. The ticket price is 80k which is not good value for money.

Wonderful, authentic, unique experience - Beautiful! A must-visit!. this Museum features the authentic, original art of Don and Mario Blanco. set on fabulous gardens of exotic plants, flowers, and a vast array of colorful bird species! Staff provided the greatest personalized service ever! also we can not recommend strongly enough their truly outstanding restaurant - its setting, cuisine and service were by far the best experienced on our trip across Indonesia!!! Mario & Wimas are most kind & accommodating hosts! Bring your camera(s)! Also do not miss the evening Gamelan / Balinese dance performance. The entire venue is truly a work of art!BTW many celebrities have spent time here including Michael J & Mick J...

Bali's own Dali!. I'm an art historian and art rules everything around me. I didn't know much about Don Blanco prior to stepping foot into the museum. I highly recommend this to everyone. If your'e only in ubud for a day go to Don Blanco Museum, the Laksi Museum (Ubud Museum) and the evening performance. You will be wowed!

One trick pony. I liked the look of the museum and the frames around the paintings were often more impressive than the paintings themselves. My problem was with the actual art. In the description under one of his paintings, Blanco explains what he believes is the meaning of life: “A fresh mango in one hand and my left hand placed on the firm [backside] of an 18 year old.” His paintings reflect this philosophy; most of his works involve young, well-endowed women posing in their birthday suits. (I'm trying hard to conform to Tripadvisor family-friendly policy; it's not easy given the nature of the art). The paintings aren't crude and I have no problem with this style of art. However, I left feeling Blanco created his paintings to live in his own fantasy world rather than seeing him as a serious artist with something interesting and worthwhile to share.

very good museum. it does not matter if you like the style of former painter Antiono Blanco or not. The museum itself is made into a piece of art and I think it is very interesting, even if you are not an art lover.Ask guidance from one of the staff members, their are some surprises in the work of this Spanish painter.
Very different museum. Not only pictures but frames to those pictures was impressive and definitely worth to see! I like that the museum is not so big so you don't need to spend there whole day)

What an interesting place. Lots of wow moments here. The artwork is lovely as is the building they are held in (there are some great countryside views from the very top of the building). There is a collection of birds scattered around the gardens, which are also lovely. Overall we spent a pleasant couple of hours here.
Interesting Museum. Very interesting art works in this museum and most of them are painting of Don Antonio Blanco. Most of his work realist and modern with many artistic nude subjects.

A must see experience. Meet the Salvador Dali of the east.. I have never seen a mansion, walls and frame built FOR the paintings. Wow. The bird cage entrance, the grounds, the restaurant and his studio were so interesting.

Interesting art collection of father & son. Parrot bird collection.. The main feature of the works of art are the frames. At first I thought 'how ugly' but by the end was intrigued. The art of the son I preferred. I also enjoyed the parrot collection that the keeper is keen to pile as many birds as possible on you. Toucans are very heavy! But can't complain it was called John!. The whole museum is located in very pleasant gardens with a good tea room.

Amazing building, grounds, view and fascinating art. Having been to Ubud many times, I am surprised that we never got around to visiting this unusual -- and unusually beautiful museum. Very interesting building set on gorgeous grounds with superb views. The art work is impressive; clearly Blanco was fascinated by (preoccupied with?) bare-breasted Balinese women! The frames he developed are also fascinating. Well worth a visit but be prepared to climb a steep hill from the road and then mount quite a few steps onto the grounds --- where you will be greeted by seven colorful parrots waiting to have their photos taken!

Art is a guaranty for sanity....maybe not always. It was a very hot and humid afternoon, so I really enjoyed the gardens and took some photos with the funny and beautiful exotic birds. The gallery is impressive, on two floors, with interesting pictures and art pieces (you cannot ignore some of the frames!), followed by the atelier with quite a number of unfinished portraits. And look at the photos, they tell you Blanco's life both private and public. At the end I invite you to sit down in the shop and watch Bali Forever, a recent movie about Antonio Blanco. I was not impressed by the minuscule glass of juice you get in the restaurant, a 'gift' attached to the entrance ticket (80.000 rupias).

Exquisite paintings. The grounds are moderately large, with all kinds of chickens and birds. We paid about 80,000 RP (sgd$8). The paintings have a distinct dreamy like romantic style, all of nude balinese women. Some of his later work was quite kinky and sexual. We enjoyed the museum very much, however only took us about 30 minutes to browse. I suppose if you took you time , it would take you a maximum 1 hour to look through . We didnt have any guides which would have been nice , like some other reviewers. We did see some guides bringing other couples around, and looking back it would have been better to have them explain the paintings to us , since some of them appeared to have some deeper meanings. The main building was two floors and had maybe 80 or so paintings, there was also an area that housed some of his son's current paintings. Near the end you could purchase some high quality prints signed by the late artist himself and with his unique styled frames (the priced ranged from USD$800 - $1500 ). There is also a gallery of photos of the late artist, his family , and guests.Overall was a great day activity and the works were beautiful. Recommended if you like art , or just want to see something uniquely Ubud.

Interesting museum. I don't plan to go here actually, I think it will be boring in the first place. I changed my mind after complete the tour. This renaissance museum offers different perspective of the art of painting . We can't take pictures inside the museum. Briefly good explained by wayan, the museum staff, I could understand what messages of every antonio blanco's masterpiece, who offer different perspective of beauty and basic culture balinese women, and his love to his family. From the restaurant, there are many good view.

knowing the art of painting. perfect sightseeing and enjoy all the paintings. Nice building and view from restaurant. They give you a drink at restaurant after you going a short tour inside museum. amazing

Great location, nice staff and beautiful paintings. We had never heard of Don Antonio Blanco but stumbled on this museum bij coincidence. His life story is appealing, emigrated to Bali in the early fifties and found the love of his life. This didn't stop him from fiddling around if the stories are true but his wife Ni Ronji was surely his muze. We loved the paintings and the staff who told us several tales about the Don!
an interesting museum. I spent more than 3 hours here!Really loved all the paintings with all its mistery.I do liked the athmosphere as well.

European and Balinese painters. The Balinese painters have the same quality to me as I saw in the local shops, nothing really special. It is more a technique than an art. The European painters are not really spectacular, better look for art in Europe.

Loved this place!. The art may not be to everyone's taste, but I loved Antonio Blanco's work and we spent a wonderful morning at this museum discovering the "Dali of Bali's" work, housed in a wonderful house set in beautiful Balinese gardens. The cafe is a cool and breezy spot for a drink or bite to eat with great views of the Ubud valley. My only disappoint was the poor selection of goods for sale in the gallery shop - would have been nice to have bought some prints and Blanco-style frames would be a great seller.

Amazing experience!. We were looked forward to visit this maestro museum. IDR 30.000 entrance fee including a welcome drink and snack. We were enjoying our visit. Guided by a young Balinese guys whose genuinely approaching us explaining us each painting meaning and without seeking a single rupiah! He explains in detail of each masterpiece as well as what are the connection with the frames. It's truly an amazing visit to this maestro museum.Looking forward to visit this place back and highly recommended to those whose visit ubud and has a taste of refining artworks.Superb!!
Have to go. Really one of a kind place. Highly Recommend. Can walk down from the main page bud centre, 30min from monkey forest perhaps? Go go go
nice museum, but. is just a big house and art colection, overall is ok, but entrance fee is not cheap and the wellcome drink have too much sugar inside.

Interesting place, pricey to get in. I had read some outdated info on this museum, indicating a much lower entry price (its about 80k to get in), and 2 cafes. The review also said not appropriate for kids - we have a 10 year old, and it was great. The restaurant at this place is pricier, but nice. The museum area has a lot of nice birds that will sit on your arm, the painting frames and buildings are interesting, more than the paintings themselves. The museum store is not good.
Intriguing. This museum is one of a kind. The building and surrounding gardens are already attractions in their own right, and let's not forget the art!
Unusual. Unexpected, different, grand. Not your normal Bali tourist event. Worth a visit, gardens are beautiful with some unusual birds to have your photo taken with.

ABSOLUTELY WONDERFUL MUSEUM. Such a vibrant and joyous museum, made me want to dance around it. Being able to sit in the studio and absorb the creative atmosphere without being hurried along was a sheer pleasure. Not to be missed. The gardens are stunning.

Family holiday. This was our first visit to Don Antonio Blanco museum. The place is very beautiful surrounding by a nice garden and tropical birds that we can take a nice photos with them. Our guide Ms. Aprilia has given an entertaining roundtrip around the museum. She was very funny and the children like her so much. Thanks Aprilia and Don Antonio Blanco museum for giving us such a nice and memorable evening during our Ubud day trip.

Stunning. Wow what an experience, beautiful property. Received nice cold welcome drink and had photo taken with a group of beautiful birds, big birds :) The gallery/house is gorgeous. The artwork very interesting, well worth a visit

Eccentric and well worth a visit. Don Antonio's museum located right in the center of ubud is well worth a visit. This was the home and the studio of the famous artist and his son still works here. We found it very helpful to have one of the staff guide us through all the painting there are some hidden gems especially in the erotic room. The grounds are great and we were able to take pictures with the exotic birds who are very friendly and don't bite. There are great dogs around as well. At 80,000 idr the entry is a bit expensive but well worth it.

Sumptuous and tacky, but absolutely fascinating. Such eccentricity. Well worth a visit!. As gaudy, tacky and overly eccentric as the collection and the museum itself is, it is well worth a visit - even if just for a quick look around if you're passing by. I don't usually find myself captivated by art - and am often bored at galleries and museums - however I found this collection fascinating. There is such overwhelming authenticity and creativity to everything, and it's hard not to be drawn in, whether you personally find his romantic-expressive kind of work appealing or not. Needless to say, there are a lot of female nudes! The garden is beautiful, and the exotic birds are stunning; the surroundings are stunning, and the garden offers incredible views over the valley and the river. Well worth a visit for all these different reasons (and, really, you won't need longer than an hour max).

visit to Blanco Museum. Our first visit to this museum in all the years we have holidayed in Ubud did not disappoint. The gardens were amazing and the son of Blanco has created wonderful surroundings and kept the complex in good condition. The early and traditional paintings of Blanco i personally preferred as his later work again for me personally found a little confronting. However i am by no means an artist just have preferences and i would recommend a visit. No need to book, just get private transport and pay at the entry.
Fabulous art. Read about the artist before you go in, there are no information sheets about the paintings as in other galleries. The building is easy to walk around but not wheelchair friendly.

Dali-esque but not quite. Antonio Blanco was born in the Philippines to Spanish parents. In his early 40's he went to Bali where he met his wife, a noted Balinese dancer. He was Bali's most famous foreign artist. He has won many awards. His house was converted into a museum and it has become a must-see destination for art lovers. Many of the paintings are of female Balinese nudes with over-sized bosoms done in a flamboyant but non-erotic style. He also created artwork involving Michael Jackson and other celebrities. Having been to Salvador Dali's museum in Figueres, Spain, the Blanco museum reminded me of Dali. By mistake, I entered the Blanco museum in the reverse order (at the exit, i.e., museum store) where I managed to take some photos of the interior. I was later told that no photography was allowed, in contrast to many international museums I have visited. I was not able to avail of a museum guide and I just walked around and let my senses direct me towards what was pleasant or not.Overall, although it did not impress me as an experienced international museum visitor, my one-hour stay was adequately satisfying. If you love art. then a visit to this museum in Ubud is worth the entrance fee.

Interesting . An interesting detour, an amazing structure that could be found in Europe houses the artwork, nudes of woman. Worth checking out for something different, 80,000 idr is a bit steep as an entry fee though.

Mildly amusing . A mildly amusing museum if you're into a certain style of mid century kitsch. Think young, topless Indonesian female nudes painted in garish blues and pinks with flamboyant pseudo-Indonesian style wood carved frames, housed in a fun house two-story gallery garishly painted in blues and reds with a high domed ceiling. Think Baz Luhrmann with poorer taste and less money. I lasted 15 minutes. The artist seemed like an eccentric euro whacko, so I would have loved a lot more info on him and how he ended up creating his lurid kingdom here in Ubud. Apparently his son has taken over the mantle and is a budding artist too, although he's been relegated one small room to display his slightly more contemporary works, consisting of collages of Michael Jackson and other folk, pictures cut up and pasted upon small paintings clearly influenced by his fathers fetish for young nudes. Give it a miss unless you're not bothered by the entrance fee.
A good place to visit. Museum, garden and location are wonderfull. Restaurant little bit expensive. The collection from Bianco is well appointed. Nice to visit this colourfull painter.

2nd Visit.. Great place to spent an hour. Stunning art and lovely grounds. The only thing I find a little strange is that no photography is allowed in the museum. Having just been to the Louvre in Paris where one is allowed to take as many photos as one wants of all the famous artwork and artefacts (including the Mona Lisa) not sure why at the Blanco Museum photography is prohibited. Anyhow, it is a greta way to kill an hour or so.

Too Expensive for the experience. We were not exactly art savvy people, but I would say that the museum is too commercialised. We paid about 80,000Rp/person for a tour of sparsely arranged artworks displayed in a 2-storey high building (despite having such a big compound). The brochure says that there is a bird park which is essentially a stand with a few parrots. I would say that money has been pumped into decors of the building rather than the actual customer experience. More could be done to enhance the understanding and appreciation of the artworks rather that creating more distractions and earning opportunities for what is essentially a museum.

a very interesting and talented artist. I had never heard of Antonio Blanco before I came to Ubud, but it's not a name I will be likely to forget now. His talent and technique are apparent in his works of art, if you can look past some of the less conventional styles. Some work is reminiscent of Di Vinci's drawings where one particular area is the subject of the attention and all other strokes are merely composition, but does this make bad art? I really enjoyed almost everything on display, and there is a lot on display!

Waste of money. We didn't really enjoy this museum or the paintings too much. It is ok to spend an hour if you are looking for things to do but feel that compared to the Dali house in Cadaques this place has nothing to offer...he is called the Dali of Bali but am afraid this is a bit of an insult to Dali! Not for us...sorry

Breath-taking art works of Don Antonio Blanco. His works are very breath-taking, he found his own way to paint. The museum, studio and resto located in a very huge area. It has a great ambiance. But the staffs were not so welcome to the local visitor. We asked for a guide, but no one helped us.

Relaxing place to visit. Heard this museum before and we decided to visit with my uncle and aunty just to find an artistic part of bali. The place is really interesting even for a not a really art lover like me. The lady guide there is really helpful in explaining the art and the story behind it. Worth to visit if you have spare time and see the works of the maestro.

3 places in 1. Really interesting place,has a bird santuary at the front where you can get some nice photos with some amazing looking birds,then you enter into Don Antonios home where it is full of art and an awesome domed roof and at the end you can have a drink or meal at the restaurant which has some nice food.If your looking for different this the place.

interesting. very very good to visit if you like modern fine arts with a very special style of painting, we met him when he was alive, he was very enthusiastic artist and talked with very funny words and made us thought before understanding him a little bit. her e can be seen some works from him with daughters or wife as the models of the fine arts, Also very unique building for the museum, .

Beautiful painting, place & concept by genius Artist!. This museum represent idea & personality of the genius Painter, because Blanco designed this place by himself. Not only I admire his works (painting & frame that become 1 unity), but also this place is actually Blanco's family real home. On my visit, I was accompanied by one of the staff: Wayan. He explained everything in details in a very entertaining way. Very good impression for me. Keep up the good work!

Celebrating an exotic Ubud art pioneer. Blanco's museum just across the bridge at Campuhan is a must visit location. A little pricey at 80,000rp but nonetheless worth it. .Blanco's specialty was erotic art adorned by the most amazing frames and set in a fantastically over the top building. Also marvellous are the exotic birds within the garden

Something Different. This makes for a nice morning or afternoon excursion. It is something different in Ubud to break up the temples, rice paddies and monkey forest. The museum has a wonderful display of tropical birds as you enter so be sure to stop and have a photo with them. The museum has a wonderful collection of art by Don Antonio and his son. The building itself is also very interesting and the grounds are lovely to wander around.There is a restaurant and bar onsite which is nice to have a drink or a bite to eat at to conclude your museum experience. If you have a spare few hours in Ubud I would most certainly recommend stopping in and having a wander around. Thank you for reading my review!

TERRIFIC ART FORMS. If one wants to see outstanding female and bali cultural art forms in the form of life size ol paintings, this is the place to be.Spanish artist, Antonio Blanco spent his life here and was inspired by a balinese lady who became his wife.Flamboyant poses and contours, rich colours and brilliance marks his art. His son Mario Blanco now runs the museum and does outstanding bali cultural paintings as well. The garden home studio has an array of birds at the entrance of the museum.The stairs that lead to the museum boasts of an idol of lord Ganesha garlanded and with offerings around it. There is a restaurant as well in the premises , and on certain days of the week balinese dance programmes are held.The welcome drink for the visitor is refreshing. Extremely polite, smiling and hospitable staff help the visitors in their way around. One can see the studio where Antonio blanco painted with the the colours he used kept intact.A must see in Bali for all art lovers.

Don Antonio Blanco Museum Maintain Domestic Heritage. Ubud tightness . Ubud is now crowded store trinkets souvenirs , art galleries , salons and spas , to a variety of restaurant and hotel . Narrow street along Jl . Campuhan , Jl . Ubud, Jl . Monkey Forest , Jl . Hanoman , Jl . Sayan , or the other way , do not diminish the spirit of the bikers or car for speeding. As if all raced to catch the next destination . Roads are no longer so friendly to pedestrians . Roads are no longer offering coolness fields or smell the fragrance of incense prayer. Ubud has changed comrades . Ubud is not like 1992 first , when my first time through the streets of Bali . Once the soft whisper of heart jerking my consciousness . Once the soft whisper of heart jerking my consciousness .Changes that must adapt to its time . The Blanco Reanissance Arts Museum or the more familiar with the Museum Antonio Blanco . To fulfill the wishes of the lover , the son of Mario Antonio Blanco Jr. , tried to provide an alternative to build a museum to ' taste ' the brave. Museum actually been initiated by Don Antonio Blanco in 1998. However, age seems unable to ' hold' . He died in 1999 .Determination to complete the task of the father that seems to make the spirit of Mario Blanco on. Various art activities both locally and internationally are followed. Mario is a hard worker . Until Don Antonio Blanco museum can implement soft opening on September 15 , 2001. To coincide well with the 1st century birth anniversary of his father, Don Antonio Blanco .Quite thick blend between Bali and Spain on the building is clearly visible on the exterior design . Built on an area of ​​2 hectares, which is a gift from the King of Ubud , the museum complex is divided into several venues . It includes the main two-story museum with a collection of 300 paintings or objects such as art collections of Don Antonio Blanco . For in the main buildings , visitors are prohibited to take pictures / photograph . This is to prevent a quick photo damaged by a flash of UV light from the flash. Given the paintings presented in ' naked ' , without being offered a glass protector . In addition of course, there are other reasons of worrying about the case of plagiarism .Supporting part of which is ' Rondji Resto ' located on the left side of the road before entering the museum . Next is a gallery / workshop . Here visitors can see some of the works of his son Mario Blanco who has a different flow of painting with his father . Gift soft , which provides a variety of souvenirs and replicas of paintings of the maestro . In other parts , visitors can watch a movie in the amphitheater or a mini cinema . In the mini- theater , visitors can watch the film series Fire Love Antonio Blanco ( Colour of Love ) . The film tells the journey of love between Don Blanco and Ni Rondji , painting models at once later married.While on the outside of the other , there is a family temple built with quite magnificent and artistic . It is located directly opposite the entrance to the museum . Behind him , there is a rare breeding birds native Bali , the Bali Starling . According bli Warsana , one of the employees of the captivity , this time bred amount is not much . ' Only ' 50 pairs Bali Starling only. Here for those who want , can buy Bali Starling with high quality . For buyers will be secured by a certificate which is proof of the authenticity of the offspring.On the right side , or midway between the family temple and museum , standing with magnificent family home also Mario Blanco . Despite having several houses in London or another city, most of the time Mario Blanco spent in the house. Therefore, almost all corners of the museum complex arranged so pretty . So that every visitor can take pictures with varied backgrounds , ranging from classic to contemporary impressions available .

Perfect outdoor venue for UWRF's closing party. With blazing lights, this year's UWRF closed on a high note - literally, as Blanco's museum is perched high above the intersecting Campuhan and Wos rivers. The museum has all kinds of curious and eccentric items to gaze at - paintings, jewelry, decor.. a world unto itself. Go for the pleasure of seeing something totally different than you'll see in the rest of Ubud's art venues.
Fantastic place to visit. What a great place to visit. Get someone to explain the adult exotic room you need to be a bit broad minded! On the whole worth while visit.

Full of Mistery. This place located at Ubud-Bali. Near with Campuhan Hill. The place was very quiet. We shouldn't bring any camera inside the Museum. We can't take a picture or the Painting. The most favorite corner that I loved very much in this Place is, the painting room. Mr Blanco are very smart for making the comfortable place for painting. Thankyou for such a beautiful museum Mr. Blanco

The best museum in the island!. Never get bored to come here over and over again.The beautiful garden will welcome you as soon as you stepped in. If you get lucky, the handsome owner, son of Sir Antonio Blanco will greet you and welcome you, then you will get forget of everything you have met.The painting that framed exclusively customized will take your imagination further and stunned a moment in every pieces.Tho the not-so-big-fans-of-painting will enjoy and luv this place.

Don't go unless you are a Blanco fan. Rp. 80,000 to get in and the grounds look great as you walk through the door. There are a bunch of large colourful birds that you can have on you arm or shoulder for a photo...... and that was about it that we were interested in. There were more birds in cages but it soon became obvious that the cage size for such large birds was far from adequate, my wife refused to look at them. The gallery building is quite impressive and to my great surprise there was a big picture of Mr Bean!! I later worked out that that was Blanco. Lots of paintings that look like they are the rough before they are finished and this guy really liked to paint female nudes. As I said I am not a fan of Blanco and if you are going to this gallery make sure you are.

Great Place to Visit. We really enjoyed this place. The artwork is crazy and sometimes vulgar, but also had some beautiful pieces. The museum and grounds themselves are worth a visit, amazing! We wandered around here for a few hours and thoroughly enjoyed it. Interesting and different.

Must-visit museum in Ubud!. The location is not far from Pasar Ubud, you can go by bicycle. As I'm a domestic tourist, I payed Rp 30.000 for entrance fee. You can take photos with genuine birds there. The museum is wonderful and it's forbidden to take photos inside museum. Everything is just wonderful there!

Fascinating.. We really enjoyed our visit to this gallery in its beautiful garden. Blanco certainly did have the air of Dali about his work. I found his paintings most interesting, thought provoking and ethereal but don't forget to look at and enjoy the quirky frames too! A pleasant place to spend a while.
Don't get excited about the 'welcome drink' ......

Agustina the guide is fabulous. Thanks to Agustina, the visit was awesome. She steaks really good French, and her explenations at the Museum were very helpfull and funny.
Thank you Agustina for this incredible moment and see you next year ☺️

Beautiful!. Gorgeous paintings and an interesting history lesson, with the photos of him and his family and the actual tools he used to paint the masterpieces shown around this beautiful gallery. The surround bird gardens are well worth a look, as is the onsite bar. Refreshing cold drink included in ticket price.

Love Art. This place is recomended for Paint Art Lover..
This place offer best paint art in Ubud..
Must visit this place..

Interesting artwork. This museum is set in 2 hectares of beautiful grounds where the son of Antonio Blanko still resides. Beautifully landscaped gardens and the museum building itself is a magnificent structure. Lovely restaurant with delightful views. Blanko' artwork is not just about the paintings themselves but the poetry and unusual framing of paintings that go with it.Highly recommend that you ask for Wayan, a guide to take you through the museum. His knowledge of Blanko's paintings and life is extensive, delivered in succinct Englishwith humour and numerous facts.The paintings offer a lot of food for thought about the artist, eccentric, intelligent, egotistical, entrepreneurial, maybe, maybe not!!,His son, Mario, also has paintings on display, completely different style and not to be missed.

Very enjoyable couple of hours. We went to have a look around the Don Antonio Blanco Museum as I had heard about his bird collection, especially the tame hornbill. We were able to stroke the hornbill as he sat on our arms and he was very gentle. Also really enjoyed the art museum, the paintings and the poems were good, some funny. The English speaking female guide gave lots of information which was very interesting. Spent a couple of hours here in the cool shade of the gardens.

The best museum and great environment. I visit this museum for the second times and this time the owner of the museum kindly introduce me and my partner to stay in their guest house for 2 days. First we were not sure about it until they show us the room wow.... It really big surprise for us, it was beautiful and we said "Yes" we stay. I recommend to travelers who visit the Blanco Museum should have a try, it worth it.

Nice place to get out of the scorching sun.. Went here to while away a few hours out of the midday sun.
