His work is sensual, erotic and sometimes confrontational but it kept my boys enthralled, specifically due to his religious reverence of women and their anatomy!The studio is preserved and the gardens beautiful to walk through, especcially because of the presence of all the exotic birds.

Peaceful oasis. This wonderful little oasis is located about 1 km from the central area of Ubud. It is a personal museum that features the artwork of Antonio Blanco. He had it built on the grounds of his villa, and the personal touch shows. Blanco is called "The Dali of Bali" because of his supposedly eccentricities, and certain of his artwork shows the same sense of humor. His style is nothing at all like Dali's, though, and some of the rest is pretty run-of-the-mill, but several of his portraits are just magic. He's more impressionistic than surrealistic, and had a Picasso-esque fascination with erotica.This museum is a great example of why there ought to be more small museums just like this: it's got a vibe all its own, and is clearly a work of passion. Oddly, my favorite things about the museum are NOT the art: it's the lovely grounds, the friendly and informative staff, the tame birds (including a magnificent hornbill) that perch on your shoulder, and Blanco's studio. The main gallery of his work is small enough to not be overwhelming, even though it's all one artist's work. Honestly, it feels like you're visiting your your very wealthy friend's house for a garden party.Plus, one of Bali's best restaurants, The Bridges, is just next door, so you can spend a tranquil hour or two here just before dusk, and then setts in for a great meal!

Rated!. We wandered up to the entrance not knowing a thing about this artist, his work or what else we might expect but we were given a brochure with pictures and information and we thought that for the small fee it was worth a shot. The whole thing was all very unexpected - the drinks, birds, architecture, art, photos and commentary on the life of this artist. We enjoyed the tour and timeline of his life running through the wall of faded and jaded photos. He was clearly a egotistical artist who was high enough profile that Elvis and Michael Jackson wanted to hang out with him. Nice to see the family legacy lives on!

Renaissance Art. If you are into art then a visit to this museum is a must to complete your museum experience in Ubud Bali.Born of Spanish parents in Manila and married to a Balinese dancer, Blanco likened himself to Salvidore Dali, though his paintings do not bear much resemblance to those of the Spanish painter. The museum, which was designed and built by Blanco himself, is set in superb grounds and housed in an unique building whose entrance is designed from his signature. The superb collection will either impress or disgust, but either way, it is an amazing tribute to this outrageous artist and his personality is reflected not only in his sensual paintings but also in the poetry, visual riddles and puns incorporated in some of his paintings. Each frame is a work of art in itself and visitors are able to visit the workshop where he created his work.

great art...nice place to visit. To be honest this is my first visit to painting & art museum, and for sure this is one of the great place to visit during our stay in Bali. The museum is build in Antonio Blanco house and it have a lot of priceless painting collection made by Antonio Blanco. Whne you get there you will be welcomed by a friendly staff that offered you a cold drink (for free). Then you will see a collection of tropical bird which almost similar like in Bali Bird Park view. After play with the bird you will see a painting gallery that connect with Antonio Blanco studio. Some painting art may contain some figure that may not appropriate to see by our children, however those painting art is covered so that can not be seen easily.My suggestion, do not hesitate to ask the museum staff to get full understanding of the meaning of severall painting art, because some painting art is very unique.

Must See. Short stay in Ubud and pouring with rain..as we were staying close by decided to visit this museum.
WOW...amazing...great collection of work by Antonio Blanco. Definite must see.

The "Dali of Bali", plus birds. The Antonio Blanco Renaissance Art Museum is a Campuhan hill-top compound, formerly the artist’s home, dedicated to all things Blanco. I’d never heard of Antonio Blanco before, but he’s known as the Dali of Bali and the site contains a neo-baroque museum, small gallery, and the studio where he used to paint, including all his paints, brushes and half-finished canvases seemingly undisturbed in the 12 years since he died. The garden is fabulous, with many different kinds of tropical birds in residence, including toucans, parrots, cockatoos and a type of small buzzard. The museum building, which one enters through a gigantic sculpted rendition of the maestro’s signature (apparently renowned as the world’s largest signature), is in questionable taste, with golden statues of women gracing the terraces and rooftop, and two floors of Antonio’s paintings, collages and drawings of women, clothed and (mostly) unclothed, all in his own especially designed wooden frames (one featuring an effigy of ET). His portraits are skillful but seriously kitschy! .A museum attendant opened two "special frames" for us to show us the extent of Blanco's romantic vision ... If you visit this museum in the right frame of mind, you'll likely enjoy it; if you go expecting a serious renaissance artist, you will be disappointed. For authentic Balinese art, visit the Neka or ARMA instread. For more information and pictures, go here: http://lmaclean.ca/2011/10/ubud-bali-a-feast-for-the-eyes-and-ears/

Weird!. Not sure if this is a museum or an amusement theme park? It's worth a look-see, given the cheap price of admission, and given the degree of import placed on this particular artist here in Bali. While I found some of the works interesting, I found the frames highly distracting... in many instances bordering on the comically grotesque or bizarre... and I felt the same way about the actual musem structure. Some of the words that come to mind when thinking about the whole space and the way the work is exhibited? Vegas? Liberace? Roccoco? Yeah, not a fan of the museum! I would instead suggest a trip to Sanur to see the Le Mayeur Musem. Pity that that one doesn't have the endowment that the Blanco Musem seems to have!

Blanco museum well worth the visit. Not actually a great fan of his work but I found the grounds and the wonderful birds well worth the admittance fee. Beautifully situated with extensive grounds that are extremely well maintained this museum is housed in a magnificent building that houses this large collection of Blanco's work and his amazing sculptured frames for his paintings, as well as sculpture and furniture. Be sure to climb up to the exterior roof level for one of the best views of Ubud and the kclose in country side.

Magical place for a crazy artist. I first came to this museum 6 years ago, but I really wanted to come back to show it to my husband. And he loved it!The place is charming, green, with those cocks, chicken everywhere. The little garden in front of the entrance is peaceful. You are welcomed with a caramel ice tea that I'm mad about!There are also some parrots before entering; I didn't remember that the last time, but today it seems to be part of the tour to be taken in picture with beautiful and coulourful parrots in your shoulder...I'm not sure it is such a good idea...The museum itself is the house of the artist, two floors. Very coulourful. Many of naked women, obviously, but I really like the way he framed his paintings; the best part of his art, I think. The guy was completely megalo and so crazy, but well, an artist. And the family is still taking care of the business.I just regret the gift shop, really poor. (only some silver jewelry of his daughter, not even a postcard with his paintings for example)But I like the place and like d to get back.

Balinese Breast Museum. You can find Blanco Renaissance Cultural Museum in about 1 km west of the Ubud market near Campuhan bridge, containing a collection of paintings by the Spanish artist Antonio Blanco who lived in Ubud until his death in 1999. Most of those paintings promote nudity in-a-so-called art of Balinese local women's breast. After consuming your complimentary drink on arrival, you will be greeted by an enormous marble entrance gate in the shape of the maestro's signature. Outside of the museum are the family's gardens where a range of birds are kept on display. They include lots of the very rare Bali starlings, parrots of all kinds, toucans and at least one bird of paradise. It's also possible to look at both Antonio and his son's Mario art studio to get a glimpse into the madness of the creative process. Most people will spin through this museum in under an hour.

It's a Trip. It is over the top but in a good way. We were greated with a fruit drink. That was lovely. We admired the beautiful birds on the way to the entrance. Then we entered the first floor of Mario Blanco's ode to himself. It's all very dramatic and really quite engaging. Do not miss it. He is a skillful artist and should be more widely seen.

Elegant exciting eye-catching and erotic. Blanco brilliant!. First and foremost Blanco is a celbration of sexuality and the female form. A sexy if sometimes confronting treat. From our first step through the entrance to our last step towards the exit Blanco was delight. Surprisingly our first treat was to hold a number of magnificent tropical birds.The attention from the staff by way of welcome drink and information and direction was always at hand and done with grace. The grounds are lovely and the building and it's decor a celebration of a gifted eccentric man whose ego was perhaps overblown. To my layman's eye the art is brilliant.Unlike most art museums I believe this one would thrill almost anyone not only serious art lovers.The whole experience of visiting Blanco Museum is just enormous fun.

Blah!. Not sure what all the rave is about, appreciated the beautiful gardens, the birds, the Versace chair was lovely - the art - no thanks. Ooh refreshing drink was nice and it did serve for a good loo stop.

expect the unexpected. first of all the art is amazing. second the grounds are amazing. third the people at this are amazing, for a mere 5 dollars to see and experience the life of an amazing human that have inspired me to live life in a more spectacular way. My journey started by being greeted by the most amazing and exotic birds, they were big, colorful and friendly, one tried to chew off my watch in a friendly kind of way when he was on my arm.The paintings are housed in this amazing renaissance dome hall, each and every painting had it's own bespoke frame that matches the artwork all designed with the artist's great sense of humour and love for women. I am amazed this place actually exist in Ubud and someone living such a colorful life here. After admiring the paintings, i visited the artist's actual studio where he created these wonderful work. My journey ended with admiring his son's work, another great artist. This trip was totally unexpected as my impression of Ubud was very traditional and conservative. A must visit attraction when you are in Ubud.

Are we in Europe or Indonesia ?. Friends recommended we visit the Antonio blanco gallery. From the moment we walked through the entrance we were captivated by the beautiful gardens and exotic birds. The actual museum building and artwork is spectacular. The artwork tells a fascinating story of the Artists life and his loves. A wonderful surprise ?

Astonishing and impressive. Antonio Blanco was given this magnificent piece of land by the King of Ubud and later knighted by the King of Spain, so he is probably permitted a bit of ego. The grounds alone are worth the admission price (still Rp 50000) and you are greeted with a cooling drink. The museum is an amazing building, maybe a little bit of Barcelona in Ubud, and the artwork is mostly focused on women and mild erotica, and displayed in beautiful and outrageous frames made by Blanco. The family still lives on the site, and the next geneation, in Marco Blanco, is also very talented.

Strange... and not in a particularly good way. First, the good stuff - the grounds are beautiful, the museum building is lovely with bold colours, twisting staircases, and epic views from the top. It is worth it to visit just for the beauty of this building.That said, I have no taste for the art of Blanco - I found it tacky. It seems to me that the artist was obsessed with sexualising women. His poems are not to my taste either. I have had friends recommend this place to me so I am sure many people appreciate his works. I don't want to criticise, I guess it was just not for me. Maybe you will love it.

Waste of money.. This place is like a grand ego monument to Mr. Blanco. If you have money to waste on looking @ boring painting of nude women then go for it. I don't know where any comparisons to Dali have come from. To call this place bizarre or weird indicates that it might be quirky or interesting. The best thing about this visit was the exotic birds, but I don't even know if the birds enjoy being placed on tourists over and over again for photo ops. I wish I had taken my 50,000 IDR and gotten a spa treatment instead.

Hideous Tourist Trap. This is the sorriest excuse for a 'museum' I have ever seen. A rich guy with a strange sense of 'art' comes to Bali with a lot of money and shamelessly builds a 'museum' to agrandize his own pathetic works. A cheesy sign part way up the hill even welcomes you to 'The Blanco Dynasty'. Once we realized the world we had naively entered we turned around and left, wishing we had not paid the entrance fee. The land could be better used by razing the buildings (and the so called art) and building a park for the indonesian people. The Puri is much better. Skip this tourist trap and continue enjoying Bali any other way possible.

Interesting Museum. The Blanco Museum is well worth a visit not just to view paintings but also to see the grounds and buildings. The paintings are interesting and often extend beyond the canvas onto the frames which are also works of art themselves. Although children may not be interested in the paintings so much, the grounds and wildlife would probably of interest.

Animal abuse at the Blanco Renaissance Museum. Yesterday I had the occasion of visiting The Blanco Rennaissance Museum. As someone heavily involved in the arts, I was excited to see the collection and the buildings. I was, however, horrified to discover how birds are being treated on you property.In a very dark and humid basement, lit only by one faint lightbulb, and smelling of decomposing feces, I saw five cages containing tropical birds. The cages were on the ground. There was no evidence of food. The smell of feces was overwhelming. Two cages in particular, were stored in the back of the basement, completely in the dark and hard to reach. The whole incident - which I have fotographed for evidence - broke my heart.I went around the propertly looking for someone who could explain what was going on. Two employees told me they were there "to be fed." This, of course, was a blatant lie. Birds are not placed in feces-ridden, humid, dark rooms in order to eat. A third employee (who spoke better English) told a different story. She said they were there because they were "still a bit wild" and that the museum staff "was teaching them how to behave" by putting them in that room. Voila.My visit was ruined by this terrible sight. It is a disgrace to have animal abuse take place on its grounds. Sincerely,Adriana Kertzer, Esq.

The Dali of Bali, or at least that's what he dubs himself, with beret, really!. Hmm, I know this is going to sound completely jerky but unlike all the other reviewers of this museum, I just couldn't really get into this place at all. I mean, I am usually someone who can appreciate any and all flavors of creativity (long as it merits it, of course, I live in New Orleans after all) but to me it just seemed like this guy, Antonio Blanco, ie the Maestro, loved himself so much he turned his home into a private museum to honor himself. So now anyone can pay to glimpse his genus. My favorite thing here was the coffee drink they give you at the entrance and the parrots but whatever, I say, it takes all kinds to color up this world from Jane Austin to Kim Kardashian to Michael Vick or Jeff Bridges, right? (also, my father is an art museum director so this might have something to do with my innoculation against the Maestro) By the way, the first big thing that confronts you at the top of the sweeping stairs is a humungous sculpture of what, you ask? his signature...before you even see what he's done to warrant what he claims to be the world's biggest signature! Wow, that says it all. I have added the picture below for your peasure.And yet how can we not have heard of him before? Move over Handcock..I think we need to start referencing people's "Antonio Blanco" next time we need to ask for someone's signature. The posing with Michael Jackson at the very end of the tour says more than I ever could.Anyway, don't feel like you have to waste your money here just to do something 'cultural' in Ubud-- go to the other museum just across the bridge (still in Ubud) The Neka, this place is awesome and actually less money for a whole lot more bang! Lots of cool weapons on display too! And if you like impressionism or even post imp. you will fall in love with some of these artists. (Think Paul Gauguin if he had gone to Bali instead of Tahiti.)

Interesting recent history of Ubud. Pros: You get to see and understand how Antonio "initially a foreigner" gets married to a Balinese dancer and then works to combine Western and Eastern elements in art and life.Cons: None really. Be open minded I guess. Tip: Perhaps more suitable for adults - check out his "erotic" art pieces with an open mind and in the name of art :)

Strange and wonderful. enter the domain of this artist and discover a world created to feed his dreams, ideas and ego. This is a little paradise that one man created and while the unusual art wont be to everyone's taste, the grounds, the exotic birdlife that has been gathered there and the view from the roof top of the gallery are well worth the minor entry charge. Great for a mid morning, pre lunch visit.

Enjoyed the art but have give a safety alert. We visited Blanco Museum last week and we both enjoyed the art of the Blanco family, very creative and the framing is amazing. The grounds and building well worth visiting. However the lighting inside is quite dim and the dark green marble floor and some steps are a trap. My husband nearly fell, it is really hard to see the steps, there are no white strips on them to show that there is a step there. He was lucky and was able to recover himself and did not go down. I wasn't so lucky, we went upstairsto the first floor, to see more paintings and I came down again, so carefully holding onto the handrail, the majority of the steps are lighter in colour, then the hand rail ends and there are two dark green steps before the dark green floor, I suddenly found myself flat on the floor. In the dim light I did not see the two steps. I have a badly bruised left elbow and right hand, a very badly bruised right knee and just found out today I have a cracked knee cap. No wonder my knee was so sore and stiff. I now have 6 weeks with a knee splint and hopefully it will mend, I am lucky it could have been much worse.So please enjoy the art and surrounds but be very careful on the stairs.

Erotisist and egotist, Blanco is fun. I visited this place some decades ago. Now that I am older I can relax and move beyond Antonio Blanco's outrageous egotism. Entry is Rs 50,000 and I received a nice iced coffee before enjoying the beautiful pet parrots from around the world. The gallery is an impressive and enjoyable building and a large collection of Blanco's paintings are well housed here. I would call it baroque rather than renaissance, but Blanco actually was a good painter despite his obvious intention to be the Dali of Bali. Relax and enjoy the fantasy but be sure to also visit the three important art museums in Ubud; the Neka Art Museum (not Neka Gallery), the Museum Puri Lukisan and Agung Rai Museum of Art (ARMA).

All I can say is please visit - wonderful museum. What an amazing experience - was totally unprepared for the beauty of the museum - we met Mrs Blanco (a celebrated dancer Ni Ronji) at the front gate and later in the gardens - what a gracious woman. Our 9 year old daughter was fascinated by the works - we will visit again - take the time to take it all in - wonderful grounds and helpful staff - willing to talk about the artist, son Mario and his paintings - it was my favourite part of our Ubud holiday.

Spanish Art In Balinese Culture. A museum dedicated to the late Don Antonio Blanco whose family still reside here and artwork being carried on by Mario, his son. The landscaping of the grounds is fantastic and we took many pictures there. The paintings in itself shows how deep is Mr. Antonio's love for Bali and its culture.

Something you have to see - great. First the grounds are just beautiful. The museum houses the work of Don Antonio Blanco, its a fairly new building and the entrance is just breathtaking. His studio was built in 1952 it is part of the museum, where today his son Mario still paints. This area is part of the Blanco home. The family temple, a small Amphitheater and a gift shop is all part of the beautiful compound. Don Antonio, born in Manila, lived in Spain and moved to Bali in 1952. He is often called the"The Dali of Bali". Its a stop you have to make.Price is about $5.
